text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with Russian tea cakes that's right
these delicious cookies are neither
Russia nor cakes but if it makes you
feel any better they are great with tea
and besides that because of their snowy
appearance they're perfect for the
holidays as well as being incredibly
easy to make so fair warning if you are
a fan of complicated procedures you are
not going to be a fan of this incredibly
simple method but anyway let's go ahead
and get started by getting our
ingredients together so in a bowl I have
a couple sticks of room temperature
unsalted butter to which we're going to
add a packed
third of a cup of powdered sugar and
right here you can see I definitely
packed it since I had a little trouble
getting it out of the measuring cup
there we go so we'll do some powdered
sugar also known as confectioner sugar
followed by a cup of finely chopped
walnuts and most recipes don't say to
toast the nuts first but I do like to
warm those up in a dry pan over medium
heat I think it makes those walnuts
taste a little nuttier but this is
optional and up to you you are the Czar
of how nutty your nuts are but I do like
to give mine a little toasting first
after which we'll let those cool before
chopping them up so I'm gonna go ahead
and add one cup of finely chopped
lightly toasted walnuts and then we'll
also need a pinch of salt as well as a
spoon of vanilla extract and it doesn't
matter which one Mexican
Tahitian Madagascar e'en as long as it's
real I'm cool with it and then last but
not least we will add our all-purpose
flour and get to mixing and the
technique we're going to use if you can
even call it a technique is what I call
the old dumping clump which means we
just dump everything into a bowl and mix
it with our hand until is just combined
and starts to clump up and I realize
this goes against every acceptable
proper cookie making technique but I
can't even pretend to care because this
works perfectly well so all I want you
to do is use one and/or two hands until
it's just combined and it starts to
clump together which means we could roll
it into balls in one great tip I'd like
to pass along here if you're not quite
sure this dough is mixed enough it's not
okay you'll know
so if you see flour or chunks of butter
just keep going until it looks something
like this which is I just mentioned just
to the point where kind of clumps
together and we're able to roll some
ball
and at this point we could stop and
refrigerate this enroll them later
or we could just do it right now which
is what I'm going to do and to assist me
with that as usual I'm going to grab my
trusty sorbet scoop which theoretically
is going to ensure each of these cookies
is exactly the same size now once we
scoop our dough what we want to do
before we place it on our baking sheet
is roll it into a nice smooth ball so
I'm gonna go ahead and do one baking
sheet full which as you can see has been
lined with a silicone baking mat and by
the way these uniformly sized balls is
just not for appearance much more
importantly it so they all cook at the
same rate
and speaking of cooking this isn't a
dough that really spreads out a lot but
it does a little bit so make sure these
are evenly spaced a couple inches apart
then once our pan is probably are ready
to bake so at this point we can transfer
those into the center of a 350 degree
oven for between 15 and 25 minutes or
until they're lightly golden and I know
that's a big range of time but I'll
explain why on the blog post but long
story short I feel that people generally
undercooked these okay so as I said I
want to cook mine until they're lightly
golden and if we peek underneath the
bottom should look like this okay a nice
light golden brown and like I said it
will review all the cooking time
variables on the blog post about
assuming we've cooked ours long enough
here's what we're going to do we're
going to let these sit for exactly five
minutes at which point we're gonna toss
these in powdered sugar and we're
actually going to do this twice so this
first time since the cookies are still
warm that powdered sugar is going to
kind of melt into the surface and form
what's almost kind of a thin frosting so
they're not going to look super great at
this point but that's fine because what
we're going to do after we given this
initial coating is let them cool
completely
and then toss them again and it's the
second application of powdered sugar
which really gives them their signature
look and by the way some people just
like to dust the tops so that you can
see a little bit of that cookie coming
through but I do prefer to coat them as
much as possible I mean for me when it
comes to Russian tea cakes if they're
not white they ain't right so I'm gonna
go ahead and finish off that second
coating and then once our tea cakes have
been sugared a second time they are
finally ready to serve with yes one more
final dusting the sugar to garnish and
know this video is not
sponsored by the powdered sugar industry
it should be but it's not but anyway I'm
going to finish up with a little bit of
hot tea
well actually room temperature prop tea
but still and our Russian tea cakes are
ready to enjoy
and while the taste is amazing buttery
nutty and just sweet enough what really
makes you so great is the texture I mean
they feel firm but when you bite into
them they basically just disintegrate
under tooth and to something that I like
to describe is very pleasantly sandy
which might sound a little weird about
you try these and you'll know exactly
what I'm talking about
okay but anyway that's it Russian tea
cakes nobody really knows how they got
that name although since I do watch a
lot of late-night movies I will take a
guess and say had something to do with a
Russian mobster but anyway mysterious
names aside these are very delicious
super easy to make and because of their
appearance are perfect for all these
upcoming holiday parties so I really do
hope you give these a try soon head over
